Articles.Content:
I honestly don't get this. The Mk1 and Mk2 (fuel tanks specifically) carry the same amount of fuel. However, The Mk1 parts are lighter for the same thing.

Yes, I get that the Mk2 parts have lifting body, but if you look at the end sides of the Mk2 tanks, you can see what looks like a hollow space.

Anybody think that that should have some fuel in it?

-SPAddict

I view it more as different looks, and look at the bright side, you can clip a mk1 LF tank inside a mk1-mk2 adapter without violating volume logic.

Then again, i really shouldnt say anything about fuel, since i habitually clip fuel tanks, even into each other, to get the desired range in a very small size/shape as i like compact vessels, and big stuff is reserved for capital ships.

That said, realistically the mk2 parts should have around twice their current fuel, and around twice the mass, but i dont mind, i can always clip mk1 parts inside mk1 parts and get said result.
Nope. The Mk2 parts need the extra space for the different avionics control systems space planes use, as well as for reinforcement against the different stresses planes experience in atmosphere.
The Mk2 parts seem to trade fuel capacity for lifting surfaces, structural integrity, and cargo capacity.
Yeah - collision tolerance. You can smack the Mk2 parts into buildings and the ground all day (at less than 20 m/s or so) where the Mk1 stuff would explode from stubbing your toe on it ;P

I agree with all of this, but as you can see at the ends of the fuselage, those spaces look to be hollow.

-SPAddict
Cylindrical tanks are more mass efficient, so the Mk2 parts are cylindrical tanks. They just happen to be surrounded by a lift-generating, heat- and impact-resistant aeroshell wrapper.

The Mk2 parts also have the advantage of using the Mk2 cockpit, which has excellent drag characteristics. In spaceplanes, good drag properties often trump mass.

Best,

-Slashy
